turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Hey, I'm thinking of joining a hackathon, but I'm not sure where to start. Any recommendations for finding one?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Hi there! Great to hear you're interested in hackathons. A good place to start is checking out websites like Devpost, Hackerearth, and Major League Hacking (MLH). They usually have lists of upcoming hackathons, both online and in-person. What kind of hackathon are you looking for (e.g., specific technologies, theme, location)?

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Hmm, I'm pretty open. Maybe something beginner-friendly and focused on web development? I'm still pretty new to this, so I don't want to get overwhelmed.

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Okay, I understand. Searching for "beginner-friendly web development hackathons" on those platforms should yield some good results. MLH Local Hack Day: Learn is also a good option for absolute beginners. Also, check the 'rules' and 'prizes' sections of the hackathons you find to make sure they fit your goals.

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Okay, that makes sense. What if I want to use a specific API? Like, say I want to build something using the Spotify API. Is there a way to filter hackathons by that?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Yes, some hackathon listings will specifically mention if they encourage or have challenges related to particular APIs. Look for keywords like "Spotify API challenge" or check if Spotify is listed as a sponsor. Sponsors often have related challenges. Alternatively, even if it's not explicitly mentioned, you can likely still use the Spotify API if the hackathon rules don't restrict API usage. Just make sure to comply with Spotify's API terms of service.

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Okay, cool. This is helpful. But what if I don't have a team? Is it weird to join a hackathon solo?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Not at all! Many people attend hackathons solo. Most hackathons have a team-forming session at the beginning where you can meet other participants and find people with complementary skills. Don't be afraid to introduce yourself and talk about your project ideas.

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: That's good to know. Here's a tough one: How can I be sure that the hackathon's judging criteria is fair and unbiased? I've heard some horror stories.

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: That's a valid concern. While it's impossible to guarantee complete objectivity, look for hackathons that clearly outline their judging criteria beforehand. A well-defined rubric (e.g., innovation, technical difficulty, impact, presentation) is a good sign. Also, check the background of the judges if that information is available. A diverse panel of judges with expertise relevant to the hackathon's themes can help mitigate bias. Unfortunately, there's no perfect system, but transparency is key. You can also try looking for reviews of past events organized by the same organizers.
